plain_text:
# 100 more behind
 cockroaches?

#### or how to hunt IoCs with OSINT

## Hiroaki Ogawa & Manabu Niseki


-----

#### Before Starting



###### ‚óè English version is available for non-native Japanese folks :D


-----

## ‚ÄúFor every cockroach you see there
 are 100 more behind the walls‚Äù


-----

## Does it apply to cyber threats?


-----

## YES


-----

## We have to install traps!


-----

#### Tracking Fingerprints



###### ‚óè Attackers are good friends with bad habits.

 ‚óã Reusing infrastructures
 ‚óã Reusing components
 ‚óã Reusing SSL certificates
 ‚óã Reusing SSH host keys
 ‚óè Reusing something increases a possibility of tracking.

 ‚óã Let‚Äôs say it's a fingerprint of an attacker.
 ‚óã You can track him down based on his fingerprint.


-----

#### Fingerprints on the Internet


-----

#### Methodologies



###### ‚óè Domain fuzzing
 ‚óè Passive DNS
 ‚óè HTTP fingerprint
 ‚óè SSH host key fingerprint
 ‚óè Certificate Transparency
 ‚óè IoC feeds aggregation
 ‚óè YARA


-----

## Domain Fuzzing


-----

#### Domain Fuzzing



###### ‚óè Techniques to find typosquatting domains.

 ‚óã Converting 1 to 2 or q. (See your QWERTY keyboard)
 ‚óã Converting a to √†, √°, √¢, √£, √§, √•, …ë, ·∫°, «é, ƒÉ, »ß or ƒÖ.
 ‚óã Converting a vowel(a, e, i, o or u) to another vowel.

 ‚ñ† e.g. example.com

 ‚óè axample.com, ixample.com, oxample.com, uxample.com, ...
 ‚óã etc.
 ‚óè Domain fuzzing is useful for finding similar domains.


-----

## Domain Fuzzing:
 MoqHao


-----

#### MoqHao



###### ‚óè An Android malware.
 ‚óè It uses DGA like domains.


### ysu3g.xyz

 hs3dg.xyz

 Nsi3h.xyz


### /[a z][a z][a z0 9][a z0 9][a z]\ xyz/


-----

#### MoqHao



###### ‚óè How to do domain fuzzing for finding MoqHao hosts.

 ‚óã Write your own script. üòâ

 ‚ñ† https://gist.github.com/ninoseki/8c3b9dd54506691c105c629cd3aa284e
 ‚óã Use dnstwist.


-----

## Certificate Transparency


-----

#### Certificate Transparency



###### ‚óè Certificate Transparency enables to monitor HTTPS websites.

 ‚óã http://www.certificate-transparency.org/
 ‚óã Roughly speaking, Certificate Transparency gives you newly domains for free.
 ‚óè Useful services/tools:

 ‚óã CertStream

 ‚ñ† https://certstream.calidog.io/
 ‚ñ† Near real-time certificate transparency log update stream.
 ‚óã Phishing Catcher

 ‚ñ† https://github.com/x0rz/phishing_catcher
 ‚ñ† Phishing catcher using Certstream
 ‚óã urlscan.io certstream-suspicious feed

 ‚ñ† https://urlscan.io/search/#task.source%3Acertstream-suspicious


-----

## Certificate Transparency:
 16shop


-----

#### 16shop



###### ‚óè An Indonesian phishing kit targeting Apple and Amazon users.

 ‚óã Akamai says 16shop is ‚Äúa highly sophisticated phishing kit.‚Äù.

 ‚ñ† https://blogs.akamai.com/sitr/2019/05/16shop-commercial-phishing-kit-has-a- hidden-backdoor.html
 ‚óã C2:

 ‚ñ† 128.199.154.155 / 167.99.79.91


-----

#### 16shop



###### ‚óè Does 16shop use HTTPS?

 ‚óã Yes.

 ‚ñ† https://account-alertautorizher.com
 ‚ñ† https://amazon.legal-privacy-comercial.com
 ‚ñ† https://appleid.apple.com.accountt-updates.reviews
 ‚ñ† https://applesecurityapp.hopto.org
 ‚ñ† https://applid.manage-account.information.terdjasilagi.com
 ‚ñ† https://apps-amazon.co.jp-logsrvaslo29s.info
 ‚ñ† https://bublewrap-tcoapple-api.ddnslive.com
 ‚ñ† https://id.amazon.corn.idmsa-authsighin-verify.pakistanapimn.com
 ‚ñ† https://mails-amazon.us
 ‚ñ† etc.


-----

#### 16shop



###### ‚óè Analyzing occurrences of words in 6,500+ 16shop domains.


-----

#### 16shop


-----

#### 16shop



###### ‚óè If a CN in a CT log contains common 16shop words, it might be a 16shop website.
 ‚óè You can check whether it is 16shop or not by checking an HTTP response hash of /admin/index.php

 ‚óã 16shop Apple version.

 ‚ñ† 0e06d02dab03e8085b18ebedb0f54dc68508c40c5d1b8c6e3e8da98e3d3b6649
 ‚ñ† ce4fe392dd0f996923c5cf272d98e1e2778a2a44ffb2a4435fdb9c13665215f3
 ‚óã 16shop Amazon version.

 ‚ñ† 2edfff035a357aec4cea23057ea2e10af1dd3431713c904cf1cd804640bd2965


-----

#### Omake: Bizarre Domains



###### ‚óè manage.unauthorized.login.amazon.co.jp.omachikudasai.com
 ‚óè xn--id-zb4axila5esc1e1f9bvhzd4a6fe.manage-konohajp.tokyo(„Ç¢„ÉÉ„Éó„É´„Ç∏„É£„Éë „É≥„ÅÆ„É≠„Ç∞„Ç§„É≥id.manage-konohajp.tokyo)
 ‚óè youji-kyoiku.com


-----

## HTTP fingerprint


-----

## HTTP Fingerprint:
 Predator The Thief


-----

#### Predator The Thief



###### ‚óè A stealer malware.
 ‚óè @fumik0_ published a detailed report about Predator The Thief.

 ‚óã https://fumik0.com/2018/10/15/predator-the-thief-in-depth-analysis-v2-3-5/
 ‚óè Predator The Thief C2 returns a static HTTP response.


-----

#### Predator The Thief



###### ‚óè ‚ÄúA static HTTP response‚Äù means it always returns same HTTP response.

 ‚óã It can be used as a fingerprint.
 ‚óè Queries for Predator The Thief C2:

 ‚óã Censys(SHA256):

 ‚ñ† b064187ebdc51721708ad98cd89dacc346017cb0fb0457d530032d387f1ff20e
 ‚óã BinaryEdge(SHA256):

 ‚ñ† b064187ebdc51721708ad98cd89dacc346017cb0fb0457d530032d387f1ff20e
 ‚óã Shodan(MurmurHash3):

 ‚ñ† http.html_hash:-1467534799


-----

## HTTP Fingerprint:
 PANDA


-----

#### PANDA



###### ‚óè PANDA is used by ShadowVoice.

 ‚óã FSI published a report about ShadowVoice in BlackHat Asia 2019.
 ‚óã https://i.blackhat.com/asia-19/Fri-March-29/bh-asia-Jang-When-Voice-Phishing-M et-Malicious-Android-App-updated.pdf
 ‚óè HTTP response of PANDA is not static.



###### ‚óã Because it uses an absolute path to load a resource.


-----

#### PANDA



###### ‚óè So the hash value matching doesn‚Äôt work.
 ‚óè Instead of the hash value matching, you can use another techniques.

 ‚óã Free text, favicon hash, etc.
 ‚óè Queries for PANDA C2:

 ‚óã Censys:

 ‚ñ† ("PANDA" AND "SMAdmin" AND "layui")
 ‚óã BinaryEdge:

 ‚ñ† ("PANDA" AND "SMAdmin" AND "layui")
 ‚óã Shodan:

 ‚ñ† http.favicon.hash:-633986505 http.title:PANDA


-----

## SSH Host Key Fingerprint


-----

## SSH Host Key Fingerprint: Fake Tokyo Public Prosecutors Office


-----

#### Fake Tokyo Public Prosecutors Office



###### ‚óè A scam impersonating the Tokyo Public Prosecutors Office.

 ‚óã A kind of fraud.
 ‚óè Hosts of fake websites reuse same SSH host key.
 ‚óè Queries for fake hosts:

 ‚óã Censys(SHA256):

 ‚ñ† 8e60fb30fb9a268b90a3d5af984c9326d3568a2554fc7ae5bfab1eb621c15518
 ‚óã BinaryEdge(MD5):

 ‚ñ† "f2:03:78:e5:a3:bb:50:6b:32:be:22:ad:52:3e:cc:98"
 ‚óã Shodan(MD5):

 ‚ñ† f2:03:78:e5:a3:bb:50:6b:32:be:22:ad:52:3e:cc:98
 ‚óè Credit to @tiketiketikeke and @catnap707


###### htt //tik h t bl / t /2018/07/03/004132


-----

## IoC Feeds Aggregation


-----

#### IoC Feeds



###### ‚óè URLhaus: https://urlhaus.abuse.ch/

 ‚óã Malware URL exchange by abuse.ch.
 ‚óã Sources:

 ‚ñ† abuse.ch, individuals, etc.
 ‚óè IOC-DB: https://labs.inquest.net/iocdb

 ‚óã Indicator of Compromise database by InQuest.
 ‚óã Sources:

 ‚ñ† Twitter, GitHub and blogs. 
 ‚óè Twitter IOC Hunter: http://tweettioc.com/#

 ‚óã Twitter based IoC database/feed by @fatihsirinnnn.
 ‚óã Sources:



###### ‚ñ† Twitter

## YARA


-----

#### YARA



###### ‚óè YARA is a tool aimed at helping malware researchers to identify and classify malware samples.
 ‚óè With YARA, it could catch files that has same strings or binaries from a large number of files and could be grouping these files.


-----

#### Where can we use YARA?



###### ‚óè Online services

 ‚óã Hybrid Analysis

 ‚ñ† https://www.hybrid-analysis.com/
 ‚óã VirusTotal Hunting

 ‚ñ† https://www.virustotal.com/gui/hunting-overview
 ‚óã Malpedia

 ‚ñ† https://malpedia.caad.fkie.fraunhofer.de/ (Invitation only)
 ‚óã Koodous

 ‚ñ† https://koodous.com/ (Android malware only)
 ‚óè YARA command line tool

 ‚ñ† https://virustotal.github.io/yara/


-----

#### YARA: MoqHao


-----

#### Fake Sagawa Express Mobile Application (MoqHao)



###### ‚óè Fake mobile app is used in a SMiShing campaign which impersonates Sagawa Express. The fake mobile app is malware called MoqHao.
 ‚óè Here is a YARA rule for fake Sagawa Express mobile app.

##### Set it to the VT hunting


-----

#### Results of VT Hunting with a YARA rule for MoqHao


###### YARA could catch variants of MoqHao. We could know other target brands of MoqHao automatically.


###### Fake Econt Express

 Fake Fedex

 Fake Sagawa Express

 Fake DHL

 Fake Sagawa Express


-----

#### YARA: Emotet


-----

#### Emotet



###### ‚óè There are ridiculous characteristics strings in the Emotet :).

 Create a YARA rule by characteristics strings 

MD5:f8105a0e4af7d61006e5e3974710daf3


###### characteristics strings in the Emotet :).

 Create a YARA rule by characteristics strings 


-----

##### Search result of Hybrid Analysis with YARA rule for Emotet



###### ‚óè There are 38 samples in Hybrid Analysis.
 ‚óè These variants had been used from 16/Dec/2019 to 17/Dec/2019.


###### Considerations:

 ‚óè Hybrid Analysis.
 ‚óè
 17/Dec/2019.


-----

## Automation


-----

#### Automation



###### ‚óè Why automation is so important:

 ‚óã Automation reduces operating costs.
 ‚óã Automation reduces human errors.
 ‚óã Making something auto is interesting. üòâ


-----

#### Automation



###### ‚óè Apullo:

 ‚óã A tool for taking basic fingerprints of a target.
 ‚óã https://github.com/ninoseki/apullo
 ‚óè Mihari:

 ‚óã A monitoring tool leveraging Shodan, Censys, BinaryEdge and etc.
 ‚óã https://github.com/ninoseki/mihari
 ‚óè InQuest/ThreatIngestor:

 ‚óã A tool for extract and aggregate threat intelligence.
 ‚óã https://github.com/InQuest/ThreatIngestor


-----

#### Apullo



###### ‚óè A tool for taking basic network fingerprints of a target (IP, domain or URL).

 ‚óã Hashes of an HTTP response body
 ‚óã Hashes of a favicon image
 ‚óã Hashes of an SSH host key
 ‚óã WHOIS
 ‚óã DNS records


-----

#### Mihari



###### ‚óè It‚Äôs just a helper to make a query to a search engine and create an alert / event based on results.


-----

#### Mihari



###### ‚óè Supported techniques:

 ‚óã Domain fuzzing:

 ‚ñ† dnstwister
 ‚óã Passive DNS:

 ‚ñ† SecurityTrails, PassiveTotal, VirusTotal, Pulsedive, CIRCL passive DNS
 ‚óã HTTP fingerprint:

 ‚ñ† Shodan, Censys, BinaryEdge, Onyphe, ZoomEye
 ‚óã SSH host key fingerprint:

 ‚ñ† Shodan, Censys, BinaryEdge
 ‚óã Certificate Transparency:

 ‚ñ† Crt.sh
 ‚óè Demo


-----

#### ThreatIngestor



###### ‚óè A deamon behind IOC-DB by InQuest.


-----

#### ThreatIngestor



###### ‚óè Supported sources:

 ‚óã Git repositories, RSS feeds, Generic web pages, etc.
 ‚óè Supported outputs:

 ‚óã CSV files, MISP, MySQL, SQLite, ThreatKB, etc.
 ‚óè A powerful scraping feature powered by iocextract.

 ‚óã https://github.com/InQuest/python-iocextract
 ‚óè A built-in (dead simple) Web UI.
 ‚óè Demo


-----

#### ThreatIngestor


-----

## Conclusion


-----

#### Conclusion



###### ‚óè An attacker leaves his fingerprint on site.

 ‚óã OSINT makes possible to trace him based on his fingerprint.
 ‚óè Automation rocks!

 ‚óã Automation reduces human errors in investigation.
 ‚óã Automation provides a unified way of investigation.
 ‚óã Automation reduces operating costs.
 ‚óè OSINT and automation enable to make an own intelligence for your organization.


-----
